addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord,
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

16 Maij
1591
. M
r
Bodeleie to my L.
In favor of
Herman Rodenburgh
arrested at his beinge hence by
Gerard de Malines
./

page.lettertext:
fol.50r
May it please yo
r
good L. being instantly re-
quested by those that were
e Deputies in the
last negotiation of
e
states
w
t
her
Ma
tie
I am
in their behalf to crave
e benefit of yo
r
favo
r
,
to
e effect of that letter, w
ch
is written by
e states
to
e
LL. of
e Councel
. It is
e suite of Her-
man Roodenburch of
Amsterdam,
who being an
assistant in
England
to
e forsaid Deputies, was
arrested in
London
by one Gerard of Malines,
upon pretense of certaine debtes. The course
that hath bin held in poursuite of his cause, is de-
clared at good length in their publike letter, and
will be signified more at large by their Agent
M
r
Caron
. Although I lett them understand
that
e states petition to
e LL. will procure
as muche favor, as
e equitie of
at cause doth
any way require: yet w
t
out my letter to yo
r
L.
they thinke their dealing insufficient. For whiche
yo
r
L. will be pleased, to pardon my bold inter-
cession, and to give me leave to intreat for some
convenient expedition in
e final ending of the
suite: wherein if
e party shall be pleasured, I
shall be thought by
e Deputies, to have written my
letters, as they have earnestly desired, very effectu-
ally unto yo
w
. Of
e states proceeding
in
e imploiment of their forces, I have signified
two daies past. It is thought that by this, they are
mette all together, so that nowe we doe expect
e
effectes of their meeting: wherof yo
r
L. shall have
knowledge w
t
e speediest opportunitie.
And so for
this present I take my humble leave.
From
e Hage. May 16 1591.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
